channel.description: Recent content in Core Concepts on Sruja Documentation

item.title: Architecture
item.description:
Architecture#

The architecture block is the root element of any Sruja model. It represents the entire scope of what you are modeling.

Syntax#

architecture "My System Name" {
 // ... define systems, persons, etc. here
}

Purpose#

  • Scope Boundary: Everything inside is part of the model.
  • Naming: Gives a name to the overall architecture.

item.title: System
item.description:
System#

A System represents a software system, which is the highest level of abstraction in the C4 model. A system delivers value to its users, whether they are human or other systems.

Syntax#

system ID "Label/Name" {
 description "Optional description"
 // ... contains containers
}

Example#

system BankingSystem "Internet Banking System" {
 description "Allows customers to view accounts and make payments."
}

item.title: Container
item.description:
Container#

A Container represents an application or a data store. It is something that needs to be running in order for the overall software system to work.

Note: In C4, “Container” does not mean a Docker container. It means a deployable unit like:

  • Server-side web application (e.g., Java Spring, ASP.NET Core)
  • Client-side web application (e.g., React, Angular)
  • Mobile app
  • Database schema
  • File system

Syntax#

container ID "Label/Name" {
 technology "Technology Stack"
 tags ["tag1", "tag2"]
 // ... contains components
}

Example#

container WebApp "Web Application" {
 technology "Java and Spring MVC"
 tags ["web", "frontend"]
}

item.title: Component
item.description:
Component#

A Component is a grouping of related functionality encapsulated behind a well-defined interface. Components reside inside Containers.

Syntax#

component ID "Label/Name" {
 technology "Technology"
 description "Description"
}

Example#

component AuthController "Authentication Controller" {
 technology "Spring MVC Rest Controller"
 description "Handles user login and registration."
}

item.title: Relations
item.description:
Relations#

Relations describe how elements interact with each other. They are the lines connecting the boxes in your diagram.

Syntax#

Source -> Destination "Label"

Or with a technology/protocol:

Source -> Destination "Label" {
 technology "HTTPS/JSON"
}

Example#

User -> WebApp "Visits"
WebApp -> DB "Reads Data"

item.title: Person
item.description:
Person#

A Person represents a human user of your software system (e.g., “Customer”, “Admin”, “Employee”).

Syntax#

person ID "Label/Name" {
 description "Optional description"
 tags ["tag1", "tag2"]
}

Example#

person Customer "Bank Customer" {
 description "A customer of the bank with a personal bank account."
}

item.title: DataStore
item.description:
DataStore#

A DataStore represents a database, file system, or any other system that stores data. It is a specialized type of Container.

Syntax#

datastore ID "Label/Name" {
 technology "Technology"
 description "Description"
 tags ["tag1", "tag2"]
}

Example#

datastore MainDB "Main Database" {
 technology "PostgreSQL"
 description "Stores all user and transaction data."
}

item.title: Queue
item.description:
Queue#

A Queue represents a message queue, topic, or event stream. It is a specialized type of Container used for asynchronous communication.

Syntax#

queue ID "Label/Name" {
 technology "Technology"
 description "Description"
 tags ["tag1", "tag2"]
}

Example#

queue Events "Event Bus" {
 technology "Kafka"
 description "Handles domain events."
}

item.title: Deployment
item.description:
Deployment#

The Deployment view allows you to map your software containers to infrastructure. This corresponds to the C4 Deployment Diagram.

Deployment Node#

A Deployment Node is something like physical hardware, a virtual machine, a Docker container, a Kubernetes pod, etc. Nodes can be nested.

Syntax#

deployment "Environment" {
 node "Region" {
 node "Server" {
 // ...
 }
 }
}

Infrastructure Node#

An Infrastructure Node represents infrastructure software that isn’t one of your containers (e.g., DNS, Load Balancer, External Database Service).

item.title: Dynamic Views
item.description:
Dynamic Views#

Dynamic Views describe how elements (Containers, Components) interact at runtime to implement a specific user story or feature. This corresponds to the C4 Dynamic Diagram.

Syntax#

dynamic "View Title" {
 description "Optional description"
 
 Source -> Destination "Description of interaction"
 // or
 Source -> Destination "Description" {
 order "1" // Explicit ordering
 }
}

Example#

dynamic "Login Flow" {
 User -> WebApp "Submits credentials"
 WebApp -> AuthComponent "Validates credentials"
 AuthComponent -> DB "Checks user record"
 DB -> AuthComponent "Returns user data"
 AuthComponent -> WebApp "Returns token"
 WebApp -> User "Redirects to dashboard"
}

item.title: Metadata & Tags
item.description:
Metadata & Tags#

Sruja allows you to attach additional information to your elements using Metadata and Tags.

Tags#

Tags are simple string labels that can be used for filtering, styling, or categorization.

Syntax#

tags ["tag1", "tag2"]

Metadata#

Metadata allows you to attach key-value pairs to elements. This is useful for storing information like team ownership, cost centers, links to other docs, etc.

Syntax#

metadata {
 "Owner" "Team A"
 "CostCenter" "1234"
 "Repo" "github.com/org/repo"
}

Technology#

Most elements (Container, Component, etc.) support a technology field to specify the tech stack.
